Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms of Rapid and Winter Cold-Hardening in Insects
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ongoing collaborative research between investigators at Miami University and Ohio State University will focus on molecular and physiological adaptations used by insects for surviving low temperature. Specifically this work will compare two distinct responses, termed rapid cold-hardening and winter cold hardening. The first is an extremely swift physiological response that occurs within minutes to hours after mild chilling. This rapid cold-hardening response is ecologically important because it allows insects to continuously fine-tune their physiological function and organismal performance to match even modest changes in environmental temperature. In contrast, winter cold-hardening allows insects to survive extreme and extended periods of cold.
This project will use a model insect, the fly Sarcophaga crassipalpis, to investigate changes in membrane fluidity and stress (heat shock) proteins that occur during cold-hardening. The role of calcium and calmodulin in regulating rapid cold-hardening will also be investigated. The results of these studies will provide a more comprehensive understanding of the integrated physiological events that enhance cold tolerance and allow insects to adjust their physiological performance to match changes in environmental temperature. This research may also provide new strategies and tools for disruption of insect pest populations and for the long-term storage of insects and other organisms at low temperature.
Another major objective is to provide outreach and professional development for teachers and students, including continued collaborations with teachers in the development and publication of inquiry-based articles in peer-reviewed, science education journals. The two laboratories will continue their commitments to training not only graduate students and postdoctoral scholars, but also undergraduate students by providing extended research experiences that include publication of scientific papers and presentations at national meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:  For many insects winter survival depends on their capacity to seasonally increase their tolerance of cold. While the physiological mechanisms of winter cold-hardening are relatively well known, a second type of rapid cold-hardening (RCH) is poorly understood. The RCH response occurs swiftly in response to brief chilling lasting only a few minutes or hours and allows the insect to survive a subsequent cold shock that otherwise would be lethal. We now know that RCH not only increases cold survival but functions more generally to enhance organismal performance in response to environmental cooling throughout the year. In nature, RCH is important because it allows insects to continuously fine-tune their physiological function and organismal performance to match even modest changes in environmental temperature.

 

Our study examined molecular and physiological mechanisms underpinning RCH and winter cold-hardening. During RCH we found that individual cells can directly sense cold and respond by allowing calcium to enter the cell and activate biochemical changes that increase their cold tolerance. Although the RCH response apparently does not involve significant change in gene expression, recovery from a cold shock involves sweeping changes in gene expression and metabolism. Apoptosis plays important roles in the selective elimination of sub-lethally damaged cells due to various environmental stresses. We demonstrated that cold shock induces apoptotic cell death in insects and that RCH functions to specifically block cold-shock induced apoptosis. In another line of investigation, we found that aquaporins, protein pores that regulate water movement across membranes, are required in the seasonal acquisition of freeze tolerance.

 

These results have improved our understanding of the integrated physiological events that both enhance low temperature survival and allow insects to adjust their physiological performance to match diurnal and seasonal changes in environmental temperature. In addition, these findings may provide new strategies and tools for disruption of insect populations, and for the long-term storage of insects and other organisms at low temperature.

 

Broader Impacts:  A major objective of this project was to provide effective outreach and professional development for teachers and students. These included collaborations with teachers in the development, classroom testing, and publication of hands-on, inquiry-based articles in peer-reviewed, science education journals. Our two laboratories continued their major commitments to training not only graduate students and postdoctoral scholars, but also undergraduate students by providing extended research experiences that included publication of scientific papers and presentations at national meetings. Lastly, we continued to provide outreach activities through a website and by giving presentations to schools, professional teacher’s meetings, and lay audiences.
